question: A woman brings her 13-year-old son to the psychiatry department after many complaints from the school that the child does not speak properly and has trouble articulating his words. His grades have also been falling. The child's Intelligence quotient (IQ) is checked and is found to be 57. Which of the following terms best describes the intellectual disability of this child?

A 3-year-old boy with a reported intelligence quotient (IQ) of 45 is brought to the clinic. His parents complain that he is unable to communicate with them. What is his degree of intellectual disability?

A 6-month-old child is brought by his parents to the outpatient department and he presents with recurrent seizures, infantile spasms, and mental retardation. Upon performing an interictal electroencephalogram (EEG), a pattern of hypsarrhythmia is obtained. What is the likely diagnosis?
What is the most likely condition associated with a pattern of hypsarrhythmia on an electroencephalogram (EEG)?
A 16-year-old female presents with complaints of experiencing seizures after awakening from sleep for 2 months. The seizures do not appear at any other specific time. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 3-year-old unvaccinated male presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of high fever and sudden loss of ability to walk and stand. He also complains of severe body aches and backaches, but bladder and bowel control are intact. On examination, he is conscious and responsive with asymmetry of limb movements. There is hypotonia and hyporeflexia with power 2/5 in the left lower limb. The remaining motor examination is unremarkable. The sensation is normal in all limbs. What is the best diagnostic test in this case?

A 3-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with a complaint of weakness in the right side of the body. The child has no history of fever. On examination, his vitals are normal and cyanosis is present. On auscultation, a murmur is found to be present. What is the most likely cause of this condition?

A 5-year-old boy presents with weakness of both lower limbs. He has no history of trauma. There is a history of upper respiratory tract infection 2 weeks back. On examination, power is reduced in both lower limbs, tendon reflexes are absent. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a complaint of fits. Past history reveals attacks of generalized tonic-clonic jerks along with atonic attacks. He has a low IQ and delayed milestones. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old male presents to the clinic with delayed milestones and fits. History reveals the fits to be generalized tonic-clonic jerks with atonic attacks associated with low IQ. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A 25-month-old boy is brought to the outpatient department with complaints of being unable to walk. The father gave a history of delayed crying and was born with obstructed labor. On examination, he has increased tone and power of 2/5 in all four limbs. Which of the following is the most severe form of the above-mentioned disease?

A 3-year-old, partially vaccinated boy presented with acute onset of fever with inability to walk because of weakness in both feet. Weakness progressed over 2 days to involve the whole of both lower limbs. On examination, he was conscious but anxious and irritable. Vitals were normal. He had hypotonia, hyporeflexia, and power of grade 2/5 in both lower limbs with mute planters and intact sensations. Upper limbs and cranial nerves were intact. What would be the most appropriate test to confirm the most likely diagnosis?

answers.option: Stool for viral isolation 48 hours after the onset of weakness
Two stool samples, 24 to 48 hours apart for viral isolation

question: A 2-year-old boy presented to the emergency room with a complaint of fever for 2 days and seizure for 30 minutes, 4 hours back. His temperature was 38°C. On examination, the throat was congested, and the central nervous system (CNS) examination was normal. What would be the most probable diagnosis?

A 5-year-old boy was suffering from high-grade fever, cough, and runny nose for 3 days. Early in the morning, he developed right-sided focal fits involving the right arm, followed by unconsciousness for a few hours. Upon awakening, he was unable to move his right arm and right leg and had a left-sided facial palsy of the lower half. What would be the most likely cause of his condition?
A child presents to the clinic with fever and left leg paralysis. What is the appropriate investigation?
Which of the following nerves is most likely to get injured during forceps delivery?
A young child exhibits difficulty walking, spasticity in all four limbs, poor feeding, and delayed milestones. Which condition is most likely indicated?
An 18-year-old male with a history of delayed milestones and anoxia during birth exhibits difficulty walking properly. Which condition is most likely indicated?

A 5-year-old child presents to the outpatient department with loss of consciousness and a history of recurrent tonic-clonic convulsions over the past year. Birth and development were reported as normal. What is the likely diagnosis?

A child is brought unconscious to the emergency room with a history of seizures. The seizures started with twisting of the neck and eye deviation to one side, then progressing to jerky movements of all four limbs of the body. What is the true categorization of this seizure?
